I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan, and (ii) a proposed grant, both to the Kyrgyz Republic for the Emergency Assistance for 
Recovery and Reconstruction (EARR). 
2.  The EARR will (i) rebuild damaged houses and improve essential public and community 
infrastructure, and (ii) restore the country’s immediate fiscal capacity to meet the sharp rise in 
incremental costs arising from the April and June 2010 conflicts. This will in turn help the Kyrgyz 
Republic with reconciliation efforts and restoration of normalcy. 
 
II.  THE EMERGENCY ASSISTANCE 
A.  Rationale 
3.  In April 2010, the Kyrgyz Republic experienced significant political disturbance, resulting 
in  many  deaths  and  injuries,  substantial  property  damage,  and  a  change  in  government. 
Community violence erupted in June 2010 with even greater casualties, internal displacement, 
physical damage, and losses. The urgent need for shelter before the onset of winter combined 
with  food  security  and  livelihood-restoration  needs  increased  the  government’s  burden. 
Moreover, energy infrastructure remains vulnerable to breakdown as a result of disrepair. While 
water  supply  and  sanitation  infrastructure  was  not  directly  damaged,  the  shortfall  in  fiscal 
transfers to maintain dilapidated systems in the country’s urban centers, especially in Osh and 
Jalal-Abad cities, will result in significant deterioration of public health conditions. 
4.  Poverty incidence for 2009 was estimated at 31.7%. While the planned increase in social 
assistance spending (an increase of 115.7% in 2010 from 2009) is expected to lower poverty 
incidence, the fall in per capita income will push more households below the poverty line.1 The 
number of households headed by women will likely increase after the emergency. Gender gaps 
in wage and employment opportunities make these households more vulnerable to poverty, 
increasing the dependence of women on social assistance to support their families. Moreover, 
with  women  receiving  more  than  half  the  social  benefits,  providing  relatively  stable  social 
assistance coverage protects households headed by women from falling into extreme poverty.2 
5.  Joint economic assessment. In May and July 2010, development partners conducted 
a  joint  economic  assessment  (JEA)  to  determine  the  economic  and  social  impact  of  the 
conflicts, and identify needs and priorities.3 With impeded international trade, a drastic drop in 
tourist revenues, contraction in agricultural output, impaired business activities, and continued 
social tensions, gross domestic product (GDP) is likely to contract by 3.5% in 2010, below the 
5.5% growth forecast made at the start of the year. Significant nonresident deposit outflows 
impaired the balance sheets of some banks, including the largest bank, Asia Universal Bank. 
These outflows are thus increasing the risk of systemic banking problems. The JEA estimates 
the aggregate financing requirement due to the emergency until the end of 2012 at $1 billion;  
$671 million is needed for 2010 alone, of which $335 million is the budget financing gap. The 
                                                 
1  Per capita output in 2010 is expected to fall from the pre-emergency projection of $943 to $826. 
2  Women comprise (i) 53% of the 351,000 beneficiaries of monthly benefits and (ii) 51% of 63,818 recipients of

3  The Asian Development Bank, International Monetary Fund, and World Bank co-led the JEA mission  with 
participation of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD), Eurasian Development Bank, 
European Union, International Finance Corporation, Swiss Cooperation Office, United Nations Development 
Programme, and United States Agency for International Development.

2 
JEA also identifies a significant funding requirement for reconstructing damaged houses in 
areas affected by the emergency. It likewise highlights the need to strengthen the delivery of 
basic  infrastructure  services,  including  water  supply  and  sanitation  services,  in  local 
communities as a way of alleviating social tensions. 
6.  Fiscal  impact.  Lower  economic  growth,  the  rollback  of  the  energy  tariff  increase, 
removal of the retail tax on energy payments, and restoration of value-added tax exemptions will 
likely result in a revenue shortfall of $86.5 million, or 1.9% of GDP (Table 1). Expenditure 
reallocation is also needed to accommodate crisis-related spending of $268 million, which 
includes  victim  compensation,  higher  security  spending,  social  infrastructure  projects, 
infrastructure rehabilitation, and bank recapitalization. With these, the 2010 fiscal deficit will 
widen to $615.8 million (13.7% of GDP) from the original estimate of $268.4 million (6% of 
GDP). 4  The  government  will  finance  $280.8  million  largely  from  net  external  financing  
($123.2 million) and use of the Kyrgyz Republic Development Fund balances ($197.6 million),5 
leaving  a  $335  million  financing  gap.  The  development  partners,  excluding  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB), pledged fiscal support during their 27 July 2010 conference of only 
$207 million.6

7.  The fiscal situation requires prudent fiscal management to balance reconstruction and 
development needs over the next 2 years with critical social expenditures for education, health, 
and  social  assistance.  Education  expenditures  include  wages,  textbook  purchases,  food, 
stipends, transportation, utility payments, and repair and maintenance of school facilities. State 
transfers  to  local  governments  cover  teachers’  salaries,  where  85%  are  women.7 Health 
expenditures include health worker wages, medicines, food, transportation, and repair and 
maintenance of health facilities. This includes support for maternal health care, especially in 
rural areas.8 In response to the emergency, the government provided one-time, lump-sum 
compensation for victims of the April and June 2010 events. An increase in social assistance 
beneficiaries  is  likely  as  disabled  victims  of  the  emergency  become  eligible  and  more 
households are likely to fall into extreme poverty.

overall budget deficit is $669.0 million (Som30.7 billion).

3 
8.  Housing crisis and reconciliation needs. Community violence in June 2010 led to 
numerous casualties and property damage in Osh and  Jalal-Abad. Approximately 375,000 
people  were  internally  displaced.  The  Rapid  Joint  Shelter  Assessment,9 conducted  by  the 
Shelter  Cluster  partners  (led  by  the  United  Nations  High  Commissioner  for  Refugees 
(UNHCR)),10 indicates that about 1,900 houses were damaged, of which about 1,700 were 
either severely damaged or completely destroyed.11 This affected about 13,500 people. The 
assessment indicates that (i) 36% of households had no access to water supply and sanitation 
services after the emergency; (ii) 41% of households lost ownership documents during the 
emergency; and (iii) more than 95% of those who were internally displaced preferred to return 
and rebuild their own homes rather than be resettled to a new location. 
9.  In consultation with the government, the Shelter Cluster partners adopted a shelter 
strategy with a budget of $26 million. This was to provide an immediate response to the need for 
shelter and included (i) immediate emergency assistance, (ii) emergency transitional shelter 
support and “winterization”, and (iii) support for displaced persons living with host families. The 
government was to follow up on this immediate response with the provision of permanent 
housing.  
10.  Of the 1,900 damaged houses, UNHCR is coordinating the reconstruction of 1,350 
severely  damaged  houses,  the  United  States  Agency  for  International  Development  is 
reconstructing 200 houses, and the International Committee of the Red Cross is reconstructing 
350 houses. Under these efforts, families are provided with basic construction materials and 
engaged in reconstruction through a self-help program with assistance of construction teams. 
UNHCR is also assisting in restoration of the property title and housing documentation lost or 
damaged during the emergency. The United Nation Children’s Fund (UNICEF) is providing 
water, sanitation, and hygiene support during the early recovery phase. 
11.  Based on the shelter strategy, severely damaged houses were eligible for 100 square 
meters  (m2)  of  built-up  area.  The  Shelter  Cluster  partners  were  to  reconstruct  transitional 
shelters of up to 50 m2 for each damaged house to allow displaced persons to resettle at their 
properties before the onset of winter. The government planned to construct the remaining 50 m2 
of built-up area through their own funds. The transitional shelter is, in reality, a permanent 
structure, which can be extended for permanent housing. Due to higher input prices, the Shelter 
Cluster partners could only provide 28 m2 of built-up area comprising two rooms.  
12.  Public infrastructure damage. The impact on public infrastructure comprises direct 
structural damage and risks of further dilapidation due to lack of fiscal resources to operate and 
maintain all infrastructure assets. If left unaddressed, both will result in infrastructure crises in 
the medium-term. The needs include the following: 
(i)  The energy sector requires financing of $180 million to address energy efficiency 
improvements; and rehabilitation and reconstruction of district heating, electricity, 
and gas systems. Also, maintenance of district heating facilities, operated by the 
state-owned KyrgyzZhilKommunSoyuz Enterprise, is likely to suffer due to the 
reversal of energy tariffs; the adverse impact will only be felt during winter. The 
World Bank will repair damaged power lines and provide heating fuel. 
                                                 
9  United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. 2010. South Kyrgyzstan Rapid Joint Shelter Assessment (3–23 
July 2010). Osh. 
10  The UNHCR-led team includes Agence d'Aide à la Coopération Technique et au Développement (ACTED), Save 
the Children, and the Danish Refugee Council 
11  About 1,450 houses in Osh province and 450 houses in Jalal-Abad province. An average house contains two

4 
(ii)  Since the emergency, many cities and small towns have been unable to generate 
sufficient  operating  revenues  to  cover  their  wage  bills,  thereby,  putting 
maintenance  of  local  infrastructure  (i.e.,  local  roads,  and  water  supply  and 
sanitation) at risk.  
(iii)  Direct damage to transport infrastructure is confined to municipal roads in Osh 
and public transport systems in Osh and Bishkek, amounting to $20 million. Cuts 
in the road repair budget need to be avoided to avert the consequences of 
deferred maintenance. Routine road works will provide temporary jobs to counter 
income losses during crises. 
(iv)  Public health has been largely affected by the lack of adequate resources to 
maintain water supply and sanitation systems. City governments are unable to 
subsidize  revenue  shortfalls  of  the  utilities.  Significant  capital  outlays  are 
immediately  required  to  rehabilitate  the  systems  and  continue  services  to 
mitigate potential stability risks.  
(v)  About 30 public buildings and 700 commercial establishments were damaged 
with a loss of $130 million due to the emergency. 
13.  Proposed ADB assistance. The EARR is in response to the government's call for 
assistance to mitigate the adverse effects of the April and June 2010 conflicts. It is based on 
ADB’s  Disaster  and  Emergency  Policy  (DEAP),12 which  offers  an  effective  and  suitable 
framework to promptly respond to emergency needs, and provides rapid funding to help rebuild 
high priority assets and restore economic, social, and governance activities after emergencies.13  
B.  Impact and Outcome 
14.  The impact of the EARR is economic recovery and social reconciliation. The EARR’s 
outcome is maintenance of essential public expenditures and rebuilding of critical social and 
public infrastructure assets in areas affected by the community violence. 
C.  Outputs 
1.  Component 1: Fiscal Support 
15.  The first component will ensure (i) uninterrupted service delivery by health and education 
institutions managed by the central and local governments, (ii) continued provision of social 
safety nets to vulnerable groups,14 and (iii) maintenance of roads and urban services. This 
entails fiscal support for critical recurrent social and infrastructure maintenance expenditures. It 
will act as a liquidity cushion against revenue shocks and, combined with the government's own 
resources,  prevent  further  disruption  of  public  services.  To  achieve  these,  certain  priority 
recurrent public expenditures in the proposed revised Republican budget for 2010 will need to 
be protected (Table 2).15 
                                                 
12  ADB. 2004. Disaster and Emergency Assistance Policy. Manila. The government requested emergency assistance 
from ADB in July 2010. 
13  A proposed urban services project for Bishkek and Osh planned for 2011 has been brought forward to 2010 to help

14  Support for the social assistance program will sustain the benefits under the reformed system and help vulnerable 
beneficiaries, especially women. 
15  The government has approved a proposed revised Republican budget for 2010, which will be submitted for 
parliamentary approval as required by the national budget law.

2.  Component 2: House Reconstruction 
16.  Reconstruction of damaged houses is a prerequisite to achieving social reconciliation. 
Building on the achievements of the shelter strategy, the government has asked ADB to help 
with the reconstruction of damaged houses. This component will assist the government in 
providing permanent houses to affected families by expanding the two-room (28 m2) transitional 
shelter for approximately 1,700 severely damaged or completely destroyed houses by 72 m2 at 
an estimated cost of $246 per m2 of built-up area. House design will be based on the individual 
household need as estimated by the UNHCR shelter database. All reconstructed houses will 
have water supply and sanitation services, electricity and heating facilities. Where sewerage 
systems do not exist, septic tanks or other safe sanitation systems will be provided.  
17.  To ensure a smooth transition from the early recovery phase of the shelter strategy, this 
component will make use of the UNHCR implementing partners. By doing this, the EARR will 
benefit from the familiarity of the UNHCR implementing partners with the affected families as 
well as technical requirements for reconstruction. This component will be coordinated with 
UNHCR to ensure a smooth transition from the early recovery phase.  
18.  The EARR will continue to engage those affected families in the reconstruction of their 
houses through a self-help program. The EARR consultants will conduct technical, financial, 
and social audits to monitor construction and ensure that construction quality is maintained. 
3.  Component 3: Community Infrastructure and Water Supply and Sanitation 
(WSS) Improvement 
19.  The  EARR  will  improve  community  infrastructure  as  a  means  of  achieving  social 
reconciliation. Community consultations by the government and ADB will determine critical 
community infrastructure, which needs improvement. This would include repair and renovation 
of community centers, schools, and health clinics. Such infrastructure improvement is seen as a 
key factor in improving social cohesion in the affected region. 
20.  Improving public health in the region will also accelerate the reconciliation process. 
Provision of clean and reliable water is the main urban basic service requirement in the cities of 
Osh  and  Jalal-Abad.  The  EARR  will  rehabilitate  water  supply  intake  works  and  treatment 
systems, and replace the water transmission system to supply continuous and reliable water to 
approximately 335,000 residents in both cities. It will develop detailed designs for long-term 
WSS improvement in the two cities to be financed through normal lending after the emergency 
phase. The proposed improvements will complement efforts of a proposed European Bank for

6 
Reconstruction and Development and Swiss State Secretariat for Economic Affairs project for 
both cities addressing water and sewerage network deficiencies.16  
21.  With the urgency for reconstruction and reconciliation, implementation assistance will 
support  project  management,  procurement,  technical  matters,  safeguards  design  and 
implementation, capacity building, information dissemination, and equipment.

E.  Implementation Arrangements

to 31 December 2010). Component 2 will support reconstruction of damaged houses and 
finance local currency expenditures for the costs of construction materials and labor (in addition

Consequently,  the  DEAP  requirement  for  imports  to  be  financed  under  quick-disbursing

25.  Given the urgent EARR needs, procurement of goods, services, and works will be 
carried out in a manner consistent with the simplified and expedient procedures permitted under 
the  DEAP  and  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time). 
Relaxation  of  international  competitive  bidding  requirements  for  works  and  goods  with  an 
abbreviated bidding and evaluation period will expedite contract awards under the EARR (as 
detailed in the project administration manual). All consultants will be recruited according to 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time).  
III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Economic and Financial 
26.  After the conflicts, the immediate task is to stop further economic slippage. By providing 
additional liquidity protection against revenue shortfalls, fiscal support will help the government 
implement  its  countercyclical  fiscal  stimulus,  fueling  economic  growth  to  make  economic 
activities more viable. Given the total destruction in many areas, any support is likely to bring 
significant  incremental  benefits  to  the  affected  population.  Support  for  the  restoration  of 
damaged houses will have beneficial economic and social outcomes. By providing essential 
public services and rebuilding infrastructure, the EARR’s investment component will have direct 
and  indirect  impacts  on  economic  revival.  Financial  and  economic  assessment  will  be 
conducted for investments made under component 3, and only those assessed to be financial 
and economically viable will be undertaken. 
B.  Governance 
27.  The 2009 public expenditure and financial accountability assessment found that the 
effectiveness of the public financial management systems varied across stages. It found budget 
classification, preparation, and execution reporting satisfactory. However, internal audits are not 
in line with international standards and the scope of external audit is not comprehensive. To 
mitigate the weakness in the government audit system, the EARR will require the government to 
establish a special account in the National Bank of the Kyrgyz Republic for grant and loan 
proceeds for component 1. ADB will regularly monitor this account, and public expenditures 
financed out of the som conversion of the loan and grant proceeds. The government will also 
submit sections of the 2010 budget execution report pertaining to the eligible expenditures 
under component 1. These requirements will be reflected in the financing agreement. 
28.  SDRD  currently  comprises  administrative  and  field  staff  appointed  to  oversee  the 
reconciliation  process.  It  has  limited  knowledge  of  ADB  procurement  procedures.  Hence, 
procurement will be conducted with assistance of the project management consultant (firm). It 
will also create a safeguards unit to ensure all activities are compliant with EARR environmental 
and social safeguard requirements. 
29.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government,  including  MOF  and  SDRD.  Consistent  with  its  commitment  to  good 
governance, accountability, and transparency, ADB reserves the right to investigate, directly or 
through its agents, any allegedly corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or coercive practices relating to 
the EARR. To support these efforts, relevant provisions of ADB's Anticorruption Policy are 
included in the loan and grant regulations and the bidding documents. In particular, all contracts 
financed by ADB in connection with the EARR will include provisions specifying the right of ADB 
to audit and examine the records and accounts of the MOF and SDRD and all contractors, 
suppliers, consultants, and other service providers as they relate to the EARR. Specific policy 
requirements and supplementary measures are described in the project administration manual.

9 
C.  Poverty and Social 
30.  By supporting critical social expenditures and rebuilding physical assets, the EARR will 
mitigate the short- and medium-term poverty and social impact of the emergency. Protecting 
social assistance expenditures will lessen the risk of reversal in the social assistance reforms. It 
will also support uninterrupted delivery of education and health services. This will address the 
possible deterioration of social services, which could occur as a result of the emergency and 
would  especially  burden  the  most  vulnerable  population  groups  such  as  poor  households 
headed by women.  
D.  Safeguards 
31.  The EARR is classified as category C for (i) involuntary resettlement; and (ii) indigenous 
peoples.  The  EARR  will  not  finance  activities  that  require  land  acquisition,  involuntary 
resettlement and/or impact on indigenous peoples, or are associated with such activities.  
32.  With respect to indigenous peoples, the classification reflects the fact that ethnic groups 
in the Kyrgyz Republic do not fit the indigenous people definition under ADB’s Safeguard Policy 
Statement (2009). However, when supporting critical social expenditures and housing, as well 
as reconciliation efforts benefiting people affected by the emergency, the EARR will exercise 
extensive due diligence to ensure that these benefits are equitable among all affected groups. 
Stakeholder consultations involving all affected families and community representatives will be 
an integral part of the EARR. Consultations will be well documented and reported to ADB for 
review and, if required, specific actions and/or programs for identified vulnerable groups might 
be prepared and integrated into the EARR’s activities. The social development specialist from 
the  project  management  consultant  (firm)  will  be  involved  in  preparing,  implementing,  and 
monitoring social programs for vulnerable groups. 
33.  The  EARR  is  classified  as  B  for  environmental  impacts.  Initial  environmental 
examinations  and  environmental  management  plans  will  be  prepared  based  on  the 
environmental  assessment  and  review  framework,  which  is  based  on  applicable  laws  and 
regulations of the government and ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009).  
E.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
34.  The benefits of the EARR, both short- and medium-term, are contingent on mitigating 
potential risks. Measures to mitigate different types of risks are incorporated in the EARR’s 
design. One important assumption is that the government is able to reestablish political stability. 
ADB will work closely with the government and other JEA partners to monitor results and track 
aid to the government. Overall, the EARR’s integrated benefits and impacts are expected to 
outweigh the costs. Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 6.  
Table 6: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures

Structural damage to houses and  ADB and the government will ensure that all designs and construction of

Lack of institutional capacity and  ADB and the government will partner with experienced development partners

IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
35.  The government has assured ADB that implementation of the EARR will conform to all 
applicable  ADB  policies  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures,  safeguards, 
gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail in the project 
administration manual and financing documents.  
36.  The government has agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the EARR, which are set 
forth in the financing agreement. 
37.  No withdrawal will be made (i) under component 1 until the revised government budget 
for financial year 2010 has been approved for submission to the Parliament; and (ii) under 
component 2 until an agreement for implementation of component 2, in form and substance 
satisfactory to ADB, has been entered into between the government and the implementing 
partners, except for specified retroactively financed activities. 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
38.  I  am  satisfied  that  the  proposed  loan  and  grant  would  comply  with  the  Articles  of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and, acting in the absence of the President, 
under the provisions of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of ADB, I recommend that the 
Board approve  
(i)  the  loan  in  various  currencies  equivalent  to  SDR32,057,000  to  the  Kyrgyz 
Republic for the Emergency Assistance for Recovery and Reconstruction from 
ADB’s Special Funds resources with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% per 
annum;  for  a  term  of  40  years,  including  a  grace  period  of  10  years;  with 
repayment of principal at 2% per annum for the first 10 years after the grace 
period and 4% per annum thereafter; and such other terms and conditions as are 
substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft financing agreement 
presented to the Board; 
(ii)  the grant not exceeding $51,500,000 to the Kyrgyz Republic from ADB’s Special 
Funds  resources  for  the  Emergency  Assistance  for  Recovery  and 
Reconstruction, on terms and conditions that are substantially in accordance with 
those set forth in the draft financing agreement presented to the Board; and  
(iii)  waiver of the requirement that quick-disbursing components finance a list of 
imports as discussed more fully in paragraph 24 of this report.
